image.altText: A father reunites with his children and wife who have travelled from Afghanistan at the airport.

props.synopsis: Afghan refugee Mohammad Rezayi fled his home, saying goodbye to his wife and four young children with the hope of sending them when he got to Australia. That was 12 years ago.

title.children: Refugee Mohammad has been in Australia without his family for more than a decade — until now

image.altText: a huge ship with beams and pipe-laying equipment

props.synopsis: Santos is pursuing the climate movement through the courts after winning a challenge brought by traditional owners against a massive gas project. Experts warn it could help spell the end of public interest litigation in Australia.

title.children: Santos turns the tables on the climate movement as fossil fuel giant fights back

image.altText: woman smiles as she puts blue drink on bench

props.synopsis: After struggling through her final year at school and hustling in a 9-5 job, Sophia Antoncic packed up and moved to a tropical island. She hasn't looked back.

title.children: The young Aussies ditching hustle culture for a slower lifestyle amid high rates of burnout

image.altText: Nurses Marita Rees, Anne Myers and Anne-Marie Jackson sit on a bench in the park, laughing together.

props.synopsis: Three palliative care nurses with decades of experience alongside death share their lessons on how to live and die well.

title.children: Palliative care nurses see us in our final hours — these are the life lessons they've learnt

image.altText: Benjamin Netanyahu grins as he sits behind two small microphones mounted to a desk in front of an Israeli flag.

props.synopsis: Benjamin Netanyahu regains favour with voters, and even though his government has lost significant ground eight months into the war in Gaza, it seems reports of his political demise have been exaggerated again.

title.children: Benjamin Netanyahu always finds a way to survive. His poll numbers just improved again

image.altText: Pat Anderson gives evidence at a parliamentary committee

props.synopsis: Uluru Dialogues chair Pat Anderson has urged the government not to use the defeated referendum as a reason to stall work on other areas of Indigenous policy, arguing the Voice was a specific answer to a specific question.

title.children: Nine months on from the Voice referendum, its architects are pushing for new action

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed and a serious look on his face. The Hard Quiz has been added behind his head

props.synopsis: Back again, I see, and clearly with something to prove. Let's see if that confidence is misguided.

title.children: Think you're smarter than a Hard Quiz contestant? I'll believe it when I see it

image.altText: An abstract image of yellow planets embedded in a purple space-time, warping under their mass.

props.synopsis: There's a 100-year-old conundrum in physics that we're still yet to untangle, and it has to do with the very nature of space-time itself.

title.children: Want a lifetime supply of chips? All you have to do is solve Einstein's incomplete theory of gravity

image.altText: Boris Johnson in a black face mask, with a tiny Union Jack stitched on it

props.synopsis: The NHS was woefully unprepared when the pandemic arrived. Will this damn the Conservative Party when voters go to the polls in a few days?

title.children: Britain's beloved NHS was kneecapped by the Conservative Party. Then the COVID pandemic hit

image.altText: A composite image of Mitch McConnel, Joe Biden, Donald Trump and Nancy Pelosi.

props.synopsis: In the lead-up to the US election, many are concerned that Biden and Trump, the two oldest people to ever run for office in the US, are running again. It's indicative of a broader issue — the average age of the US congress has been climbing for decades.

title.children: The debate has US voters asking, how old is too old to be president? But it's a bigger problem than Biden and Trump

image.altText: Two people embrace outside of a court house

props.synopsis: Five years after a 29-year-old Yamatji woman was shot dead on a suburban street in regional WA, her family want the officer who pulled the trigger moved to a different beat.

title.children: Family of WA woman shot dead by police anxious for answers ahead of inquest

image.altText: Trevor Andrei stands in a short with his name on the front at his property in regional Victoria on a summer day

props.synopsis: Trevor Andrei is a self-described doomsday prepper and survival guide. But it's not just people fearing the end of days that are coming to him for help, as the cost-of-living crisis bites hard.

title.children: For this doomsday prepper, it's no surprise his phone is ringing off the hook

image.altText: A woman with long blond hair and dark rim glasses smiling

props.synopsis: How do we ensure that our teenagers reach out to us when things take a turn for the worse? Bec Sparrow shares the top three tips she has learned from the experts in Parental As Anything Teens this season.

title.children: Three lessons for parenting teens that we can learn from the experts

image.altText: A hand holds up blocks that read 01 July. Stacks of paper sit below

props.synopsis: The new financial year will bring a suite of changes for Australians. Here's a breakdown of what's taking effect on July 1.

title.children: The 2024-25 financial year is almost here. Here's how July 1 changes could affect your wallet

image.altText: A composite image of a bright red and white sign that says 'coles' and a white sign that says 'woolworths' with a green icon.

props.synopsis: Food, mortgages and power bills — with the cost of living dominating, will this week’s supermarket inquiry make a difference?

title.children: Will the cost of living ever go down? Food prices are on the rise despite multiple supermarket inquiries

image.altText: A pristine white sand beach with palm trees and turquoise water.

props.synopsis: Blessed with pristine lagoons and coral reefs, New Caledonia was hoping to attract more Australian tourists. After civil unrest struck, businesses are now thinking about survival.

title.children: Australians were evacuated from this tourism hotspot weeks ago. Locals believe they can help it rebuild

image.altText: A composite image of Olivia and Hannah Lemin next to a bottle of red citronella liquid.

props.synopsis: Health authorities are investigating claims two Perth sisters were served insect repellent instead of juice at a western suburbs restaurant.

title.children: Children suffered 'burning stomachs' and 'tingling hands' after restaurant allegedly served insect repellent, not juice

image.altText: Nigel Farage sits in a brown armchair, pointing at a photo of Vladimir Putin.

props.synopsis: Ahead of a historic UK election, five Facebook pages secretly operating from Nigeria are using Kremlin-aligned propaganda and AI-generated racist imagery to sow "division and chaos".

title.children: UK Conservatives say ABC analysis that points to foreign interference operation 'highly alarming'

image.altText: A speckled white bowl of lentil bolognese ragu topped with vegan parmesan cheese and fresh basil.

props.synopsis: Whether you batch-cook on weekends, want leftovers for work lunches or love the idea of making one or two meals to last the week, here are four recipes to consider.

title.children: Prep for the week ahead with four dinners that leave plenty of leftovers

image.altText: A young white man in a white tshirt and blue apron, stands in a busy commercial kitchen looking stressed

props.synopsis: The Bear and The Boys are among the shows returning for highly anticipated seasons this month.

title.children: A bunch of TV series returned in June. Here’s what you should be watching

image.altText: Man with arms in the air in celebration on cricket pitch

props.synopsis: India sets the highest total in a Twenty20 World Cup final before shutting down a spirited South African run chase in the final two overs in Barbados.

title.children: India sets T20 World Cup record to beat South Africa in heart-stopping final

image.altText: Two PNG census officials complete paperwork as they chat with a woman in the shade near a building.

props.synopsis: PNG has not had an accurate count of its population in 24 years and estimates vary by millions, but with a new census underway and officials heading to all corners of the country by road, boat and helicopter there could soon be a reliable number on exactly how many people are in the country.

title.children: No-one knows how many people live in Papua New Guinea but a census is hoping to change that

image.altText: Mary Goulding

props.synopsis: Mary Goulding was a rising star of New Zealand basketball. But after a near-fatal car accident, she sustained a brain injury and was put in a coma for 12 days. This is the story of how she went from learning to swallow, talk and walk again, to elite Australian basketball.

title.children: Mary Goulding was told she'd never play basketball again. This is how she defied the odds to return to the court

image.altText: Two armed police officers block an intersection near the Israeli embassy in Belgrade, Serbia.

props.synopsis: The attacker — believed to be part of a puritanical Muslim sect — is shot dead after shooting a police officer in the neck at a guard house at the Israeli embassy in Belgrade.

title.children: Crossbow attack at Israeli embassy sparks hunt for extremists in Serbia

image.altText: Mark Cavendish crosses the finish line in the opening stage of the 2024 Tour de France.

props.synopsis: Tour de France great Mark Cavendish barely finishes within the maximum time limit in the first stage, as Romain Bardet picks up the first yellow jersey of his career.

title.children: Cavendish struggles with vomiting during brutal Tour de France opener as Bardet claims yellow jersey

image.altText: A man at a workbench cuts a piece of engineered stone. He wears a full head covering.

props.synopsis: The manufacture, supply and installation of this common kitchen benchtop material is outlawed from this week on. For silicosis sufferers, it's a step forward all too late.

title.children: Engineered stone is banned from tomorrow, but a 'generation of pain and suffering' is still to come

image.altText: People looking at an undercover market stall selling clothing, gifts and homewares.

props.synopsis: Social enterprises are for-profit businesses that tackle a social problem at the same time as doing their work. They're booming in growth and a new scheme aims to add rigour — so the good work keeps getting done.

title.children: Businesses doing good are doing well. A certification scheme aims to keep it that way

image.altText: Koto teacher helping her student, who is vision impaired, play the instrument.

props.synopsis: Koto musician Takako Haggarty works with a special school in Brisbane, to teach disabled students to play the instrument — helping them gain skills in mobility and emotional regulation.

title.children: Ancient Asian musical instrument helps empower children with disabilities

image.altText: forensic and police officers attend an alleged murder scene in casino nsw

props.synopsis: NSW Police received a concern for welfare call to a home on Johnston Street, Casino shortly after 1:30am on Saturday, but the call wasn't acknowledged by a radio operator until much later.

title.children: Woman dies in alleged DV murder in northern NSW as police investigate why response took almost an hour

image.altText: Dyson Heppell stands on the MCG after Essendon's AFL loss to Geelong.

props.synopsis: Essendon was looking to make a statement by beating Geelong and pushing its top-two credentials, but the Bombers were outscored by 10 goals to two after half-time as the Cats ran out 45-point winners.

title.children: 'A series of unfortunate events': Bombers glumly reflect on second-half collapse in loss to Cats

image.altText: Xavier Coates covers his face

props.synopsis: With Origin III just 19 days away, Xavier Coates limped off the field as the Storm edge past the Raiders in Melbourne.

title.children: Maroons winger Xavier Coates 'not great' after limping off during Melbourne's victory against Canberra

image.altText: A smiling man in a suit casts a ballot at a crowded polling station.

props.synopsis: Iran will hold a run-off presidential election to replace the late President Ebrahim Raisi, after an initial vote sees the top two candidates fall short of securing an outright win.

title.children: Iran's presidential election goes to a run-off vote, with sole reformist challenging hardline nuclear negotiator

image.altText: Anthony Albanese looks sternly off to the distance.

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese has criticised tech behemoth Meta for claiming social media hasn't harmed kids, and for threatening to block news content.

title.children: Prime Minister slams 'arrogant' tech giant Meta over harm to kids and media

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith in a suit and tie

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is distancing himself from a decision to award a medal from King Charles to former special forces soldier Ben Roberts-Smith.

title.children: Anthony Albanese says awarding Ben Roberts-Smith with a King's medal 'certainly wasn't a government decision'

image.altText: Stylised sepia picture of a man in black clothing and a balaclava holding fire arm, crime scene tape and police in background

props.synopsis: Two days after being sentenced, the man dubbed the "bicycle bandit" died. Kym Allen Parsons robbed 10 banks and attempted to rob an 11th. Who was he and how did he remain on the run for so long?

title.children: This ex-cop was on the run for two decades after 11 heists. He was finally sentenced this week — now, he's dead
